title: Will any disputes over IAEA access to Iranian sites be referred to the Joint Commission before 1 July 2017?

This may pass and President Littlefingers may sign it, but it specifically is not about the nukes.  Still at zero here.
The recent  U.S. certification of Iran's compliance of the JPOA makes it very unlikely the IAEA will refer anything to the joint commission before July 1.
Going from 1 to zero because there is still no evidence that Iran is actually violating the agreement.

Trump administration says Iran complying with nuclear deal

Iran has been generally cooperative about the nuclear deal. Honestly, I'm more worried about the Trump administration ripping up the deal and thus nullifying the joint commission more than I'm worried about Iran starting trouble. Well, this kind of trouble anyway.

Still seems unlikely as Iran has been and will likely continue to be cooperative, but raising from 3% to 5% just because of Trump. I think it's unlikely he "tears up" the nuclear deal, but he may be pressured by Saudi Arabia and Israel (where he has significant business interests) to place more pressure on Iran's compliance with the agreement. Will face pressure from Congress as well obviously. As Khalid mentions below, any aggressive moves by the Trump Administration will be "telegraphed well in advance."

Key Findings and except are included below:
1) Iran for the second time is in violation of the cap on 130 metric tonnes1 of heavy water. In addition, Iran continued to produce heavy water during the two-week period after the IAEA learned and pointed out that it had reached the cap.

Iran will try to hide relevant sites and deny access to sites, it is their history. The question is how much back and forth negotiations will the IAEA inspectors allow before making a referral? I do not believe either side will be quick to let the situation erode enough to jeopardize the agreement but it is a real possibility.

Given the time frame and a new President there may be changes towards the Iranian sites.   Iranian leaders don't seem to like HRC (1) and if elected it looks like she will be serious about compliance (2).   I'm not convinced anyone is watching closely enough about that right now.

Iran has apparently complied with inspections to date.
https://www.quora.com/Has-Iran-complied-with-IAEA

More no than yes
Despite Khamenei's rhetoric, more O&G projects are underway with international community
It doesn't make sense to jeopardise all their efforts to meet the JCPOA, cut deals and then ruin things
Actually does that answer the question? I might be answering, "Will Iran breach the terms of JCPOA" instead
Not for a while.  There are quicker and less risky ways for everyone to get on everyone else's nerves in the short term.
Change in US admin could change priorities, and US / Iran co-operation.
I think everyone manages to keep a lid on everything.
Iranian hardliners may seek to derail diplomatic normalisation, but Iran's economic interests lie in abiding to the deal
Much more likely with a Trump victory

Unlikely, however Iran will likely continue to  press their advantages towards nuclear capabilities, including upgrading their centrifuges (1),   sooner or later their sampling process could have an error and a violation will be detected.
long timescale so there's no sense in being too low when so much stuff can happen

The IAEA is forbidden to access most of the sensitive military sites under the wording of the agreement.  Easy enough for Iran to ensure that nothing awry occurs at the limited sites the IAEA is actually allowed to monitor.
Leaving 5% because there's a year to go, but on the evidence of the last eight or nine months, all concerned are co-operating.
I don't see the current Iranian administration fooling around wit this.

Long lead time.  New US administration with new objectives in Jan. 2017.
Iran, so far, has been eager to meet requirements; increase in business activity slower than anticipated, not sure what the motivations will be in early 2017.
Iran will likely try to challenge and push the limits.

I think Iran is motivated to keep this deal in place until they recover somewhat from sanctions.  I don't see a big appetite for the US/Western countries to stir the pot given the current state of their misadventures in Iraq and Syria (and Afghanistan).  Still, the political climate surrounding the power struggles in the middle east is inherently unstable, so there is still definitely a non-zero chance.  10% is the midpoint of my guesstimated range of 5-15%.
Tensions in region escalating - geopolitical fallout inevitable within next 12 months.

A combination of new administration in Washington after January and possible announcement by another country in the region that they will begin work on defensive building of nuclear capabilities will force the issue.
Not with the big multinationals now setting up proper shops in Iran.
German intel report charges Iran seeking illegal nuke, missile tech
May IAEA board report on Iran verification was innocuous  - unlikely to cause trouble as they ramp up oil production. Might do later though!
Iran has so many other ways to misbehave.
New violations or new President might make a difference...
I would like to say zero, however, I will go with 10% in case of a snafu.

I'm betting that Iran will allow access as per the nuclear deal at least until they are able to feel the positive effects of sanctions relief, which IMO would be about a year from now.  Starting low, might raise later.
